Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Self-Sensing and Sensitivity: Advanced Composites for Traditional Non-Destructive Evaluation (NDE)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant provides funding for research on the development of fiber-reinforced composite materials that are easy to inspect using standard non-destructive evaluation techniques. Non-destructive evaluation detects damage in structures, much as a doctor's x-ray detects a broken bone and such techniques are critical to the safety of a wide variety of industrial and commercial structures such as airplanes and pipelines. Nondestructive evaluation is common for metallic structures, but its application in non-metallic systems is much more challenging. To address this challenge, approaches developed for self-healing materials will be adopted. Materials will be processed that contain microencapsulated contrast agents to make damage easier to detect during magnetic and x-ray inspection of fiber-reinforced polymer composites. This research will take inspiration from nanoparticle-based contrast agents used for medical diagnostics and will apply them to advanced composites. The contrast agents will be synthesized and integrated into the materials and, in parallel, sensing systems for these contrast agents will be developed.

If successful, this research will enable quantitative analysis of damage in composites using highly accepted, readily available non-destructive evaluation techniques. This will improve the safety and reliability of composites. Lighter, more efficient structures would be enabled as engineers gain confidence based on improved damage detection in the structures they create. Graduate and undergraduate students in this research will be part of an interdisciplinary project combining solid mechanics, instrumentation and materials chemistry and the results will be published in journals and presented at national and international conferences. Educational initiatives include peer-based instruction and other self-directed techniques in engineering courses that will foster creativity and improve retention of STEM students. Aspects of this research will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses as well as an engineering summer camp for high school students. All course materials and demonstrations from the research will be available through the research group's website.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of the project titled CAREER: Self-Sensing and Sensitivity: Advanced Composites for Traditional Non-Destructive Evaluation (NDE) is the development of a new composite material that can highlight damage using a magnetic bruise.  This advance is a step toward creating new materials that can begin to address one of the major limitations of fiber-reinforced composites, damage tolerance.  While fiber composites have many useful properties, they are lightweight, stiff, and strong, these materials can be significantly degraded when lightly damaged.  This limitation is frequently addressed by designing composite parts that are overbuilt to limit the chances of an unexpected failure.  By fabricating new composite materials that can help users identify damage quickly and easily, allowing for composite parts to be designed closer to their optimum.  This project demonstrated the potential of these self-sensing and self-healing composites through the completion of several project goals. These project outcomes included the  development of a novel self-sensing composite that can indicate damage through visual, thermal, and magnetic modes, the development of a targeted self-healing material that can accurately place self-healing component in a specific location, and the development of a novel two-capsule self-sensing system that can enable the autonomic indication of damage in a composite. In support of the materials synthesis and characterization outcomes described above, a magnetic-based scanning system that can accurately map damage indicated by the magnetic self-sensing material was constructed and validated. The educational outcomes include the development of a flipped classroom approach for undergraduate introductory mechanics courses. Implementation of that classroom methodology at the department level based on in-class results. Development and implementation of engineering modules for use in a summer STEM camp intended for high school students.  During the course of this project three graduate students were mentored and several undergraduate students participated in the research project.  Three journal articles were published and two patents were granted based on the research that was completed during this project. 


Last Modified: 09/28/2020
Modified by: Michael W Keller

While fiber composites have many useful properties, they are lightweight, stiff, and strong, these materials can be significantly degraded when lightly damaged.
